Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Geochemical Study of the Nature and Evolution of Mantle Upwelling Beneath Ross Island and its Relationship to Tectonics in the West Antarctica Rift System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
Existing petrologic and geochemical data for Ross Island volcanic centers are sparse and outdated, with the exception of the well-studied Mt. Erebus stratovolcano. Therefore, understanding of the genesis, evolution and tectonic context of alkaline magmatism on Ross Island is extremely limited. The PIs propose to conduct a field and laboratory based geochemical, isotopic, and petrologic study to investigate alkaline volcanism across the entirety of Ross Island. This study will provide: state-of-the-art isotopic abundances of Nd, Sr, Hf and Pb; pre-eruptive volatile concentrations as determined in melt inclusion studies; petrological and mineralogical information, and major and trace element concentrations for samples from Mt. Terror, Mt.Bird and Hut Point Peninsula. When combined with the published compositional and isotopic data from Mount Erebus, and the published Ar-Ar ages from Ross Island, these data will provide essential information on the nature of the mantle source and the processes and causes of magma genesis beneath Ross Island.

Broader impacts:
This proposal will train two PhD students, broaden the participation of underrepresented groups, promote and enhance secondary educational experiences in a formal class room setting, and encourage new investigators to become involved in USAP. The proposed research includes a collaboration with ENS, Lyon, France. This study will also establish a suite of well-described and geochemically well-characterized samples available to other researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ross Island Antarctica is home to McMurdo Station, Antarctica’s largest research base, and Mt. Erebus, the world’s southernmost active volcano. Prior to this study, however, petrologic and geochemical data for Ross Island’s three peripheral volcanic centers – Mt. Terror, Mt. Bird, and Hut Point Peninsula – were sparse and outdated. These three volcanic centers were active between approximately 0.3 and 4 million years ago and are situated radially around Mt. Erebus, each 30-40 km away from the active Erebus crater. Our field team collected over 125 new samples from Ross Island, concentrating on the three peripheral volcanic centers. These samples allowed us to examine the nature of mantle upwelling beneath Ross Island and to better understand how Ross Island fits into the larger regional geologic setting of the West Antarctic Rift and the southwest Pacific.

The geochemical composition of Ross Island samples provides information about the origin and evolution of Ross Island lavas. We analyzed the major and trace element concentrations and isotope compositions of over 60 samples from Ross Island. These findings helped us to answer questions about the mantle sources from which the lavas were derived and the processes that took place prior to eruption. Specifically, we examined the hypothesis that Ross Island is the manifestation of a small mantle plume. Evidence that suggests the presence of a mantle plume beneath Ross Island includes the radial symmetry of the peripheral volcanic centers around the active Mt. Erebus, the large volume of erupted material at Ross Island, elevated mantle temperatures beneath Ross Island, and the presence of hydrous minerals in the peripheral volcanic centers suggesting a cooler wetter periphery compared to a hotter drier core.

Our new isotopic data reveal general groupings within each peripheral volcanic center in terms of their Sr, Nd, Pb, and Hf isotope compositions, suggesting small-scale mantle heterogeneities beneath Ross Island. The overall range in isotope compositions for the peripheral volcanic centers is greater than for Mt. Erebus, suggesting that there is increasing mixing with surrounding asthenosphere and lithosphere on the outer part of Ross Island. Many samples from Mt. Bird show a deviation from the main Ross Island trend in terms of Nd-Hf and Pb-Pb isotopes, implying that they have mixed with a component or components different from that of the other Ross Island lavas. Finally, we found a trend in the Pb isotope compositions of Mt. Terror and Mt. Bird lavas in which the Pb isotope compositions decrease with increasing distance from Mt. Erebus, which could indicate that the plume-like isotopic signature at Mt. Erebus is progressively diluted with increasing distance. As we continue to interpret this recently completed dataset, we will be able to draw further conclusions about the origin and evolution of Ross Island and to better understand how it fits into the regional geological picture of West Antarctica and the greater southwest Pacific.

In addition to these scientific findings, this project provided the opportunity for our team to participate in outreach activities including a National Geographic blog (http://voices.nationalgeographic.com/tag/antarctica-2012/), in which we wrote about our field experience in Antarctica and communicated directly with students from across the United States. We also visited local Laramie Wyoming high school and grade school classes to share our experience and talk about the important science that is being conducted in Antarctica. Our project also introduced two new top-tier researchers to the US Antarctic program and provided broad field and laboratory experience for two graduate students.
